name: A lake near the equator held together by gravity.
description: Once upon a time I was camping in my van in the vast Mojave Desert. I was laying down looking out the sliding door into the distant horizon. In my field of vision, as I was laying, the world was horizontal: sky extending infinitely to the left, Earth towards the right. After a couple minutes the realization and visceral experience hit me that “up” was a relative concept. That if I could imagine myself temporarily detached from Earth’s gravity, then I would be able to see that up/down, in a general sense, is a linguistic construct used for general communication. With closer examination one could see it’s an immersive illusion facilitated by the immense effect of Earth’s gravity; without gravity, the idea of up/down begins to fall apart. After that experience I would apply that understanding to all other landscapes. This is especially intriguing when considering bodies of water and how it “sticks” to Earth. This NFT illustrates such a perspective. It’s curious that a horizontal visual orientation is actually just as accurate a depiction of reality than any other.
